author: potuz
content: I've been going like a broken record, but the problem happens when syncing in locked step, that is the EL is not just snap syncing but getting actual batches of blocks to execute, and the CL is doing the same, while at the same time serving the ones they have. This typically happens on a starting node for about 64 blocks, because a starting node starts from a finalized checkpoint that happened  6 minutes before starting. But the issue becomes a bit worse if you are starting a node after 2 weeks without finalizing. I believe this is the measure we want to have, not a theoretical one of what clients should do, but an actual performance of current clients (what they actually do) in these conditions. It looks like it's increasingly hard to get this on mainnet/tesnet, but at least we should gather this on large devnets as a naive lower bound.

author: .fjl
content: I also want to propose a small change to the EL commitment after devnet-4

author: .fjl
content: specifically, I want to propose that we elide empty requests data elements in both the commitment and the list provided to the CL

author: .fjl
content: the idea behind this is ensuring we have a stable empty requestsHash that is not dependent on the fork

author: .fjl
content: right now, the 'empty' requestsHash is `sha256(sha256(0x00) || sha256(0x01) || sha256(0x02))` but this could change in the next fork when we introduce more request types.

author: .fjl
content: having a defined empty hash regardless of fork simplifies EL testing

author: .fjl
content: anyway, I will create a proposal for these changes for devnet-5
